docTitle.titlePart:
Induction of antigen specific T regulatory cells to
suppress inflammatory responses by tolerogenic
vaccination

front.div:
Inflammatory disorders, such as asthma, could be detrimental. Dust mites may cause
50-80% of asthma cases. No effective treatments, particularly those targeted to antigen-
specific inhibition, are still lacking. In our previous study demonstrated that co-immunization
of DNA and protein vaccines together as tolerogenic vaccination into animal could inhibit
inflammatory responses in a antigen-specific matter. Using dust mite induced asthma as
model, we assess the immunotelarogenic effect of co-immunization. Mice immunized with a
Derp1 tolerogenic vaccine were examined their ability to prevent this experimental asthma by
assessment of infiltrations of eosinophils and lymphocytes into lungs. The immunization with
the tolerogenic antigens not only induced significant decrease of inflammatory responses in
the lungs, but also to inhibit Th2 cytokines and production of IgE. The induced tolerogenic
responses are associated tightly with the generation of CD4+CD25-Foxp3+ iTregs. We
observe that these iTregs exhibit phenotypic markers including IL10+, CTLA4low, GITRlow,
PD-1-and ICOSlow, which differ from those documented natural CD4+CD25+ Tregs and
iTreg. Blockade of TGF-β1 could demolish the induction of this iTregs and suppressive
responses. This tolerogenic vaccination induces the iTreg via TGF-β1 and present a novel
therapeutic strategy to treat or prevent inflammatory disorder related diseases.
